Posts.Title: Scared about today

Posts.Content: Next week on Good Friday I will have my last cycle of chemo. I have been reflecting on what I have learned about myself from the chemo experience. There are 5 themes. Here's my list. 1. About Courage. I am risk adverse, a total coward. I never seek out thrills and theme parks make me sick. I am not ashamed to admit that. At 1am this week I was lying in hospital with a head injury, requiring a blood transfusion and waiting as the medics tried for the 4th time to get a blood sample from my exhausted veins. And I thought....this requires courage. I know I have no choice, but I think I have been brave. Not just during this minor assault but since discovering the lump in my breast in September last year. I know many of us are uncomfortable being described as 'brave', but I have decided that I am and that is the first thing I have learned about myself. 2. About Gratitude. I am very lucky. I was lucky before I had cancer and I am still lucky now. After chemo, I have a few days where all I feel is the side effects. I don't feel pleasure in my usual things, in food, in music, in fun. I don't sleep well. But as the days pass things come back to you, you might sleep better, to be able to taste a grape, or go to the toilet (that's been major for me) and after these events you feel intense gratitude. This week I have felt gratitude for things I would never have thought of before. I am grateful to the person who donated the blood I had transfused on Monday night. It has made a huge difference to my ability to get about. I am grateful that chemo will give me the chance to get better. I am grateful it will soon be over. 3. About Compassion. I started visiting the Macmillan site after my diagnosis. I was lonely and scared. Every time I asked a question, someone would say 'that happened to me too, ' or ' it gets easier,' People used their difficult experiences to help me and that's what I needed the most. It was such a dark time but there were people there all along. The more they reached out to me the easier it got. I made connections with people through the experience I have had and I understand how totally essential that is for me and for others. When people post on Macmillan for the first time, I remember. I remember the fear and confusion and the pain. I remember the anxiety I felt before my first chemo, I feel for them. 4. About Knowledge. I have learned a lot about breast cancer. Not near as much as others but enough to help others sometimes. It feels good to do that, to help people as I have been helped myself. That knowledge empowers people to ask questions and to not always accept things we are uncomfortable with. Knowledge is power. I know how it feels to experience chemotherapy. I expect to be asked about that experience many times over the next few years and will always be honest and open about it. 5. About Acceptance. I knew at the beginning of this experience that there would be things I had no control over. I had no control over how I would be affected by chemo. I had to accept the side effects, there was trial and error with anti-sickness meds and steroids. In the same way I have to accept that I have no control over how effective chemo has been. Since I had my surgery first I won't know how chemo has impacted on my cancer. I have to accept that I can't control the outcome, no one can. But I can control how I move forward from chemo. This is my life, it is not a certain thing but I can still enjoy it and experience happiness in it. I won't miss chemo! But I do believe that enduring it has made me a stronger and more compassionate person. I hope that feeling will help me as I move forward to the next phase of treatment and beyond, back to my life! Fiona...xxx

Posts.Content: hello Lizz this article has really annoyed me For 2 reasons. firstly she treats her experience of chemo as if it affects everyone the same way which is obviously not the case. I often compare the chemo experience to childbirth becayse everyone has a different experience and you get the horror stories which can terrify you before you know how it will be for you. It is very unhelpful. secondly she wonders why the hair replacement info is not widely shared....probably because most people don't have the resources to spend thousands of pounds on sticky on hair. I know hair loss can be very upsetting for a variety of reasons but  both my friends with BC did cold cap and it worked for them. i didn't use it because I hate the cold and didn't want to have the time spent doing chemo prolonged. So i was bald for 4 months. I didn't love that experience but I had a wig which I could have worn if I wanted to. I didn't though and that was my choice. i understand the yearning for normality because getting cancer takes that away from you but I put those feelings into doing normal things with my kids and my friends when I felt well enough inbetween cycles to do that. I often felt happy at those times and it helped me get through chemo.  you will get great support going through chemo and the chemo club thread is great, this article not so much! fiona
Posts.Title: Decca Aitkenhead in the Guardian

Posts.Content: Hello Jaki i hope you get the low score you are hoping for. Becoming a mum for the first time can leave you feeling so vulnerable even without adding in this horrible factor.  my children are 7 and 12 but like you I was worried about how chemo might effect my ability to look after them as my husband works away from home.  I have only had a couple of people telling me that 'I'll be fine' it's the one comment that I just can't let go. I always start off by saying that actually right now nobody knows how I will be be....not me, not the doctors, not anybody because the facts are are right now my future is uncertain so while I'm all for positive thinking I like to ground that thinking in realism and facts. I am learning to accept that uncertainty and it helps me if other people can learn to do that too. I find that since saying this people are less likely to tell me that I'll be fine! i understand also that friends and family want to help and that sometimes their words are just evidence of how helpless they feel in the face of this. Good luck with the score and hope you get the outcome you are looking for and can enjoy your time with your precious daughter. fiona

Posts.Title: Lifestyle changes?

Posts.Content: I start radiotherapy on the 19th May which is exactly 8 months to the day after I found the lump in my right breast while having a shower. I am having 19 sessions.It will be two months since I had my last chemo. It will be 7 months since I had my breast surgery.  I have been feeling really reflective today. I still visit this site every day because I feel supported here and I want to connect with others going through this too. I have been really up and down over the last two months. I honestly (stupidly) expected to feel better as soon as 3 weeks had passed after my final chemo.  I was frustrated when I still felt tired and achey. I caught a stinking cold that took 2 weeks to shake off and I have been mortified by how much weight I have put over a very short period of time.  However, I am doing my best to eat well. I continued to walk my dog almost every day during my illness. I have started yoga and once my rads is finished I'll go back to swimming twice a week.  I've changed my photo to reflect what I look like now....2 months of hair growth....very fluffy but it's almost a buzz cut! I have decided that chemo is a poor beautician and a worse hairdresser!  Im not sure what this thread is about really except I wanted to just check in and say thanks for all the support I've had a various points during this experience. God only knows what kind of state I would have been in without it. Fiona

Posts.Title: Lifestyle changes?

Posts.Content: I was talking with a friend today about how I feel I need to live my life in a different way once my treatment is over. I am triple negative so I know hormones were not a factor in stimulating the cancer to grow and I am still waiting to hear if I have the Gene mutation.  I have read about mindfulness meditation and being part of a survivor support group as being beneficial in recovery so I am going to do that. I am going to start yoga...or resume it....I stopped going to class because I couldn't fit it in.  I am not going to apply for the job that I thought I should apply for because it was the natural next step for me in terns of where my career was. I knew it would stress me out. I am going to give more time to my friends and family who have got me through this shitty time. I am going to try and eat better food....antioxidants etc. I might drink green tea instead of tetley! That kind of thing. I just wondered what changes, if any, people planned to make to their lives and why?
Posts.Title: Lifestyle changes?

Posts.Title: A bit of a ramble....and a thank you!

Posts.Content: I am 4 months on from chemo and have completed treatment. I'm Triple Negative so not getting hormone therapy.  I haven't had a period since my 2nd cycle of chemo and that combined with hot flushes and other aches in my joints lead me to suspect that I it has triggered an early menopause. I've had my kids so not over troubled but because my mum has osteoporosis I have asked my doctor for a bone density scan to see if I am at risk. Due to being TN I always knew I would get chemo and I just hope it has worked but I feel a bit neglected my by Doctor. I had such great care during treatment but now I feel a bit like chemo has impacted on my body in ways that I might not even understand and it doesn't seem as if follow-up care is offered.  My younger brother had bowel cancer the year before I was diagnosed with BC so I am now getting screened for that too. This was supposed to happen before I got my diagnosis but the Dr didn't get back in touch after promising to do so. I don't want or need to be at the Dr's now..I don't think its a psychological need I am feeling but I know that nothing would have happened if I hadn't gone up to surgery to ask. Has anyone else experienced damage after chemo and had to ask for specific support or scans? I knew so little about cancer before that I don't even know what kind of damage people do cope with. Fiona
Posts.Title: Long term impact of chemo?

Posts.Content: Thanks Julia Whenever I tell my friends that my periods have stopped their immediate response is ....lucky you! Obviously if I hadn't already had my family they wouldn't say that but they are seeing it from the perspective of convenience rather than health! I was as regular as clockwork and unlike many of my friends wasn't bothered with problems connected with my periods. However I accept either outcome....that they are gone or may return. The latter is better given the osteoporosis risk associated with reduced oestrogen levels.  I should have talked about thus more fully with oncologist but I felt I was wasting their time as its not major and aged 43 the menopause wouldn't have been a really long way off...although after cancer 5 years definitely has a different value.  this is only the 3rd time I've seen my doctor during this process which includes the original visit after I found my lump. It feels a bit like I couldn't move for health professionals telling me that I might find things difficult emotionally after treatment concluded but I didn't get told very much at all about the physical long term implications of chemo. That said I do not regret having it and do feel that  given how hard it was on my body...it must have been hard on the cancer too!  The upshot of that is I feel happy and optimistic....but the aches and pains are a reminder of what I've been through and I don't know if they are a direct consequence simply of the menopause or something else....feel a bit clueless in that respect.  Fiona
Posts.Title: Long term impact of chemo?

Posts.Title: Long term impact of chemo?

Posts.Title: Long term impact of chemo?

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone...both for compliments on my 'do' and info! I do accept that scans are not offered to detect the possibility of recurrence although ironically my friends and family who have not had experience of BC find this very surprising and I am often being asked about that at the moment. My understanding is that early scanning and detection does not change prognosis in terms of recurrence of a secondary nature. I have made my peace with that. I think I am more concerned with improving the functioning of the bits of my body that appear to have been damaged.  The ache I feel in my body after I've been sitting in one position for a while is a new thing for me and I'm trying to establish if it is temporary or permanent. I feel my body and joints have aged and sometimes seized up altogether. My oncologist did say to contact him anytime but I took this to mean if I thought the cancer had come back ...otherwise I see him in 6 months time.  I actually have no pain or discomfort related to my surgery at all so I can see by some responses here that I have been lucky in that respect.  I feel so old inside though....but appreciate it's still early days.

It must hurt so much and I think getting counselling would be a great idea.  My brother just finished treatment for bowel cancer the day I was diagnosed with breast cancer. Posts.Content: Hello Jayne thanks for your response! i also declined that trial as I am TN and cancer was grade 3. I felt that I wanted my treatment to be personalised to my needs rather being decided randomly. As the recurrence rate for TN Is higher I felt this was a risk I was not prepared to take. I was actually unhappy about the info about the trial because it was available to those with 1 or 2 lymph nodes affected but the risk for those with TN or Her2 + would be higher and that was not made explicit I felt.  i have since found out that I will be getting rads to axilla in addition to tumour site and am happy to go with this decision.  Fiona
Posts.Title: Lymph node surgery

Posts.Content: Hello silvercloud I feel for you having to make that difficult decision. I am also 43 with young children but because I am triple negative i knew that I would get chemo and that it would make a big difference to my prognosis. I finished chemo 6 weeks ago and am about to start radiotherapy. I was really anxious about having chemo but in some ways it wasn't as bad as I thought it might be. You get through it. I am glad that I was able to tolerate it in order to give myself the best chance of survival but of course there never really was a choice for me and clearly there are no guarantees either.  As others have said....it's your choice and once you have made it you have to feel that you can live with it.  Good luck fiona
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: Hello Dee thank you so much for your honesty in describing the outcome that removal of your lymph nodes had for you. I totally agree about fear of the cancer diagnosis affecting decision making also because sometimes the decisions are made for us and sometimes we don't have the information required to make an informed decision. I 100% agree we need to be asking those questions and it's very hard because we are being flooded with new info about the cancer as well. i appreciate you taking the time to share your experience so much and reading such accounts makes me feel more secure about the option of radiotherapy rather than further surgery. Although I know there is still heightened risk there now. thank you fiona
Posts.Title: Lymph node surgery

Posts.Content: I had 8 lymph nodes removed during my breast surgery but because cancer was found in two of them it will require further treatment once I'm finished chemo. I have 2 questions. First does anyone know on what basis they decide to go for surgery clearance rather than radiotherapy to lymph? Second would anyone who has had clearance surgery separate from breast surgery share their experience?  If they do the surgery then that will happen before radiotherapy and I would just like to know more about how manageable that is....although after chemo I can't actually imagine it being worse!  Thank you Fiona
Posts.Title: Lymph node surgery

Posts.Content: Good luck for tomorrow yvonne.... My surgeon told me my lymph nodes didn't look good when he did SNB and I was so worried about getting biopsy results. So I know how horrible that feels.  I am grade 3 invasive ducal too but TN.  Thinking of you for tomorrow. fiona
Posts.Title: Results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Thank you Julia, dreamthief, susie, positive and chloe for those replies. That is so helpful. i realise how little I know about this and that info will really help me with questions once I see consultant again. I am worried about lymphedema. I had mammoplasty breast surgery at the same time as the lumpectomy and SNB and was really happy with the outcome and recovery so am not keen to have more surgery if it can be avoided.  Fiona
Posts.Title: Lymph node surgery

Posts.Content: Hello Pop I also have breast cancer that has spread to the lymph. I had my surgery 2 months ago.  I started chemo this month. Like you I was very scared. Everyone's experience of chemo is individual to them but I can honestly say that while I did get side effects it wasn't as bad as I thought it might be. I had FEC and will get T for cycle 4,5 and 6.  I get my second cycle on the 30th and while I am not looking forward to it....I am no longer anxious about it.  Fear makes the wolf bigger than it actually is....that describes my experience but I understand that for others  that may not apply. I felt quite down on the 3rd day after my first chemo I think in part because I had psyched myself up to do it then felt quite deflated after realising how many more there are to do. But the time has come round quickly and I have been happy in between and busy seeing friends and enjoying my life as much as possible.  Each chemo I get moves me forward to where I want to be and closer to recovery. That's the mindset I am using to handle things.  You will get great support here! Fiona.
Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed breast and lymph node cancer. Chemo in January...

Posts.Content: Hello Funda  I have the same thing except my periods stopped after my second cycle of chemo. I asked consultant if I might now be going through early menopause ( I am 43) .....the consultant told me .....maybe but that it wasn't a reliable form of contraception! How I laughed....! Like I need contraception right now! He said the flushes would be hormone related and are re-adjusting. I am going to go to the doctor if my periods don't come back though.  Fiona
Posts.Title: Feeling hot and cold at night

Posts.Content: Hello pepys What a lovely positive and inspiring post!  Its great to know that there will be good things again. sounds amazing too!  Fiona
Posts.Title: There's light at the end of the tunnel, ladies...

Posts.Content: Good luck for tomorrow Lynn. I felt so much better once Id got my first one done. Then you know what you are dealing with. I ate a lot of melon after FEC....and tomato soup. I wasn't exactly a model of nuttition though!  Fiona
Posts.Title: Chemo Starts Tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hello. Lynnwad I used the black nail polish with a layer of hardener too for the Taxotere bit of chemo. I wasn't sure if it would work but I thought it was worth a go.  I used it every time for cycle 4, 5 and 6.  My fingernails are fine....but every one of my toe nails has turned purple and is in the process of falling off. It does reflect the fact that when I had Taxotere my feet were really sore but my fingers were OK. A bit numb but no pain.  i don't know if wearing the polish made a difference but it's an easy thing to try and who knows!  Fiona
Posts.Title: Chemo Starts Tomorrow

Posts.Content: hello Judy I agree with everything you said on this subject. Before I got cancer I remember Jessie J shaving her head for charity and everyone saying how brave she was and I didn't think it was brave. It's good that she raised money perhaps but certainly no awareness. Now I have had cancer and have been bald as a result of chemo I would take no comfort at all in others doing this either to fundraise or in some misguided attempt at empathy. How you react to losing your hair is personal. I knew it was a temporary thing and viewed it that way but the idea that others would shave their heads and therefore feel they have insight to the experience of having cancer is just the dumbest most insensitive idea ever.  I am glad to know others feel this way as I thought it was just me!  Fiona
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Agreed Karen I found T difficult especially the first time and I was vocal about that. But I got through it and knew as pointed out by dreamthief that a reduced dose was an option. I chose to continue with it and my 2nd and 3 red cycle were manageable and not as unpleasant.  The experience of going through chemo is a personal one....to me the experience reminded me of childbirth because people had their stories and some were scary and traumatic but the vast majority got through it relatively well.  In any case a few months later  it almost feels like it was somebody else doing those cycles.....except for a few longer term chemo related gifts!  I am so glad I got through it and would hate to think that fear results in people opting out of treatment....until you've had it you don't know how it is going to affect you. fiona
Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: Hello papa smurf i cant answer your question about whether being not being able to feel the lump is good or bad but just wanted to say hello. I joined this site at the same point as you just before surgery and SNB. At the moment you probably have lots of questions that have not been answered yet. I got the results of my breast lump biopsy 3 weeks after my diagnosis and I found that really helpful as I had a much clearer idea of what I was dealing with, the type of cancer etc. it may be that your question can only be answered by waiting unfortunately and that's the difficult part. Please do continue to post with questions or concerns.....or if you want to rant, cry etc we will will listening. fiona
Posts.Title: New diagnosis

Posts.Content: hello everyone ive just ordered a book called tea and chemo by jackie Buxton which has great reviews about the experience of having BC.  does anyone have any recommendations for books they have read?  only 7 more sessions left of radiotherapy and I'm feeling much better....doing yoga looking forward to going back to swimming and will be returning to work after the summer. i feel like life is about to return to 'normal' but I'm obviously not feeling exactly normal but i think I'm doing ok.  Any suggestions?  I have read the online article by dr Peter Harvey about after treatment finishes already. It's very good. fiona
Posts.Title: Moving forward reading recommendations?

Posts.Content: Thank you both for suggestions  I just finished the humans by Matt haig which is funny and poignant. the best book I have read recently is all the light we cannot see by Anthony doerr not a light read but amazing and beautiful. fiona
Posts.Title: Moving forward reading recommendations?

Posts.Content: Hello papasmurf you are doing all the right things exercises and walking. My surgery also involved mammoplasty so different but I was overwhelmed by how weak I felt and I also had days when I felt very low. You sound really positive. I know you will be feeling nervous about the next stage in process but just keep doing what you are doing and look after yourself ...getting your strength back most important thing. sending positive vibes back at you! fiona
Posts.Title: Discomfort increasing

Posts.Content: Hello papasmurf you are doing all the right things exercises and walking. My surgery also involved mammoplasty so different but I was overwhelmed by how weak I felt and I also had days when I felt very low. You sound really positive. I know you will be feeling nervous about the next stage in process but just keep doing what you are doing and look after yourself ...getting your strength back most important thing. sending positive vibes back at you! fiona
Posts.Title: Discomfort increasing

Posts.Content: Hello Susie I am tempted to read all his other books now but I also need to re read it to process the info as there is a lot there to take in. But the basic message is clear and accessible and it's definitely a book I would recommend. Not sure if I would make it through not the last goodbye without becoming a weeping wreck though!  Fiona
Posts.Title: Vitamins and supplements?

Posts.Content: Hello Carol & Iona I had a look at the chorlella that sounds like an easy adjustment to make. I feel like there is so much to learn just now in terms of lifestyle changes but it is all very self directed through reading etc as there is not much info that is shared via medical routes. I have just finished reading 'anti-cancer a new way of life'  By Dr Serven-Schreiber which I feel so described how I want to live beyond this diagnosis that I was often in tears reading it. I know that I need to improve my nutrition and that will benefit my health generally, I need to continue to exercise but make yoga a central pillar in that regime. I also need to opportunities to meet with other people who have gone through this experience and make connections with them.  I hope to work one day less once I return to work to get a better balance between work and home.  I have no genetic factor and the cancer is triple negative therefore not stimulated by hormones. I might never know what caused my cancer but I do know that I could live better and that when I do I feel better so I am seriously trying to plan for that...and implement it. fiona
Posts.Title: Vitamins and supplements?

Posts.Content: Hello Iona looks like we are both trying to do the same thing. My appetite is back though and I am trying to eat good food and get structure back into my eating.  I guess we both know that it's early days for recovery but like you I want to do what I can to facilitate it! I feel happy that I am having a good breakfast porridge and wholemeal toast a because I have time I make a juice in the morning because I like them and it makes me feel good. But in terms of vitamins and supplements etc I don't have a clue so hopefully can learn from what others are doing too. The most beneficial thing to my health will be kids going back to school on Monday! Hurray!  fiona
Posts.Title: Vitamins and supplements?

Posts.Content: I cried every single night before bed for the first month....so I drove my husband mad too....he couldn't help but was trying his best and I was putting on a brave face all day...mainly for my kids who are still young then I became a crying mess just when I needed to sleep.....it wasn't good but thankfully once my treatment plan was in place things got better. I still have some days that I worry and i think everyone does. i have had surgery (mammoplasty/ lumpectomy/ SLNB) and finished chemo 2 weeks ago. I start radiotherapy next month and once that's finished I'm done as I am triple negative so no hormone therapy.  You are right to ask the questions you need to on Friday. I have had really good care but I think sometimes the detachment required to do their job can come across in quite a blunt and stark way. Good luck for Friday. fiona
Posts.Title: Results of surgery

Posts.Content: Hello  not exactly sane situation but my cancer is grade 3 and I had cancer in 2 out of the 6 nodes they sampled. The outcome for me after my surgery to remove the 30mm tumour was chemo then radiotherapy to tumour site and axilla. There was debate about whether to do further surgery to lymph but radiotherapy was expected to give the same protection as surgery but with less further disruption.  I know it's scary when it's in your lymph but my surgeon told me its treatable when I got a bit stressed by it.  Fiona
Posts.Title: Results of surgery

Posts.Content: I would make getting better your full time job for the rest of your treatment. I have been off for 6 months now and onto half pay. Worrying about how to pay bills in addition to dealing with cancer must be awful so I am glad that was one less thing to worry about. I am a teacher and I care about doing my job well and there is no way I could have done it during chemo....especially Taxotere which hit me hard. Take the time ...and get better. Fiona
Posts.Title: work or not?

Posts.Content: Hello Teresa totally understand your desire to have a holiday ....I'm off to london this weekend for my birthday and as a treat to mark end of chemo. i am triple negative and the cancer was grade 3 and in my lymph. I was told I would get 5 weeks to recover from chemo I am seeing consultant in a weeks time to get my radiotherapy dates etc. I don't have any medical knowledge at all to contribute but that would seem to only make a couple of weeks difference if you were to start after your holiday.  I would be asking the questions Barbara suggested.Xx fiona
Posts.Title: Delaying radiotherapy for a few weeks - could it be detrimental?

Posts.Content: Hello Jeanied thanks for the recommendation! I read all the time...lots of different things!  Fiona
Posts.Title: Moving forward reading recommendations?

Posts.Content: Hello Sarah I started feeling ill about 2 months before my diagnosis, I started vomiting about once a week. I would lose my appetite and was not able to eat and all I could do was sleep it off I felt cold to my bones. I always went swimming on the days I didn't work Monday and Friday and it only happened on those days. I couldn't understand how my swimming would be connected though as I have been swimming for years.  Then I ended up at the doctor with a sharp pain in my side. The dr thought it might be kidney stones...I remember thinking I don't fancy having kidney stones.....that sounds rubbish....a week later I found a lump in my right breast and had my cancer diagnosis within 10 days.  I stopped swimming and was only sick one more time, after telling my children that I was ill. I haven't felt that way at all since having my surgery and chemo. I was sick after my first chemo was that was definitely because of chemo.  After I found my lump friends kept telling me that breast cancer didn't have symtoms so it couldn't be cancer.... I believe that the cancer was draining my energy capacity and that's why it only happened on the days where I was swimming. I had been pushing myself on those days. I don't know this for a fact but I think that's how it was affecting me.  I think it was connected. fiona
Posts.Title: Dizzy and fatigued

Posts.Content: It is frightening and nothing anyone can say makes it less so. When my surgeon performed the SLNB after my surgery he told me after surgery that my lymph nodes looked 'squishy' and that they would either be removed by surgery or zapped by radiotherapy after I had chemo. he was genuinely surprised when he came back into my hospital room and found me sobbing! He even asked why which despite my emotional state I found quite funny as I'd just had breast surgery, and had been told in was in my lymph nodes too...I kind of felt I had good reason to cry!  when I explained that hearing it was in my lymph worried me i did take comfort from knowing that it could be treated.  I am saying all this because you have every right to be frightened....I was too and I still am. I am also worried about the lymphedema risk which I think would be higher for me if they removed whats left of my lymph nodes.  As a new member to the site posted a few days again....this is scary shit....and it really really is.  i don't have the medical knowledge to address your concern about the time factor between the surgery abd radiotherapy caused by the chemo phase but perhaps someone else will. I hope you get some answers that will help you. fiona
Posts.Title: Results of surgery

Posts.Content: Dear Felon i am sorry you are having such a tough time with chemo. I can't share advice about your regime as I was on FEC-T but for me the t bit was really tough too. i totally identify with what you are saying about the guilt feeling of being so dependent on husband but agree with every word Julia has written on that subject. i was a very independent person and in many ways llived a separate life from my husband because he works away from home and i was working part time and being responsible our school age children the rest if the time. Earlier on this year I did articulate to my colleagues...is it normal to feel this tired? then I felt guilty for moaning becayse many of them were working full time with children the sane age and husbands who also worked away from home or long hours.  of course it became apparent for me that it wasn't normal to feel that tired....when I started to lose weight and vomit before finding a lump in my breast. i am telling you this because my husband and I are are much closer since my diagnosis. I know it can go the other way too! But in letting my husband do more for me and more to help I feel very grateful but he also has developed a much greater appreciation of how much I was doing.....and I just felt I was doing the minimum as I am not really very house proud...minimum standards apply!  I have a much stronger feeling of being appreciated and cared for .....something I found it very difficult to do but had to accept and actually people who love and care about you want to do that. You would do that if he was in your position. I tell my husband how grateful I am for all the things he is going because that's important. I also have had to say to him when i needed more help....a conversation I hated having but I was becoming exhausted after T....and people can't tell by looking. I had lovely pink skin .....caused by steroids but was actually so anaemic that I couldn't even walk my dog. I looked well though! so well that my husband went off to work after my 5th chemo and I collapsed in the house while my children were asleep. Cue ambulance etc  now he and I are less complacent about the effects of chemo. So once again I will say sorry it's been tough so far but do not feel guilty the care he is giving you now is what a loving partnership needs to be about. Once you are better and your strength returns you will in time find that you are stronger than you have ever been and the enhanced gratitude you feel for your life and loved ones will help you to move forward from this horrible time.....that's what I want for myself and would wish it for you too. hugs, Fiona.
Posts.Title: breast cancer, looking for advice,experiences,support

Posts.Content: Hello lizz dreading chemo and feeling scared is understandable. I am trying to understand if its those feelings alone which are making you feel that  you want to refuse chemo?  i completed chemo 2 months ago and while it's no picnic I'd do it all over again if I thought it would stop a recurrence. I always knew I would be getting chemo so I didn't have to make any difficult decisions. Perhaps when the results come back from DX test you will feel in a better position to decide. It must be really tough. For myself I feel very happy that I have done everything I could to get rid if it but I know there are no guarantees either way.  Good luck  Fiona
Posts.Title: Thinking of turning down chemo

Posts.Content: Hello lizz im glad the result to the test has helped you move forwards towards making a decision. feelings of uncertainty are the worst and so even though you feel an understandable reluctance to do this at least you know that the chemo is likely to have a significant impact on your prognosis. I think you put up with the side effects...whatever they may be if you have clearly thought about what you are doing and why, as you clearly have.  Fiona
Posts.Title: Thinking of turning down chemo

Posts.Content: Hello YorkA I felt the same as you when got the news about the lymph. I felt really worried, sad and tearful but the surgeon said the same to me...it's treatable and I hold onto that. 2 out of 8 sampled for me had cancer but I am hopeful that means that the nodes were doing their job and catching it. It is really hard but it does get better. Even with all the ups and downs of surgery and treatment it does get better.  I am in bed recovering from my second chemo cycle. And although it doesn't have much to recommend as an experience each one that I complete is moving me forward and I do feel better about that...even if I did spend some time crying last night and this morning...I am a wimp about illness!  Thinking of you Fiona
Posts.Title: reigning in the fear

Posts.Content: Hello YorkA Sorry you are in this situation too. I am also 43 and have grade 3 ductal breast cancer. I have had surgery and am now getting treatment. It is so hard in the beginning. My children are 7 and 12 and because I had started vomiting and losing weight before finding the lump and getting my diagnosis I really believed that I had secondary cancer and that I would not see my children grow up. It was so painful. It felt like a bereavement.  I have gone from feeling like that to feeling positive and happy most of the time but of course our experiences are all personal and others might not feel that way. My positivity comes from accepting things the way are. Yes I have cancer, yes that's shit. Yes the cancer has spread to my lymph nodes but that is still treatable. My scans do not show evidence of secondary cancer. So every day that I can do normal things and be a mum to my boys and feel well is a good day. I have no control over the final outcome but I need to find a way through the difficult days to survive this. If I allow fear of death to paralyse me from living now then cancer will have successfully taken away even more of my life than it already has. I don't have control over many things in this situation but I do have some control over how I handle things. I go to a support group and I am active on this site....it has been a great source of support to me and the people on it a a great source of knowledge, experience and compassion.  When the appointments start filling up the diary and surgery and treatment start it does keep you busy too and leaves less time to brood.  It's not a easy path but there is only one direction to go on it. I wish you all the best as you find your way.  Fiona
Posts.Title: reigning in the fear

Posts.Content: Helly lizzy very happy and positive post ....good to read!  Might check those out....I'm 9 weeks post chemo and my eyebrows are starting to grow back and if I hadn't dusted off my tweezers I'm pretty sure I could have been sporting a reasonable beard by now but still no eyelashes! I miss them fiona
Posts.Title: EYELASHES!

Posts.Content: That must be such an amazing feeling! Have a fab holiday! fiona
Posts.Title: I think I am a NEDdy

Posts.Content: Yesterday I was out getting supplies at the chemist for starting chemo in 2 weeks and I stopped at a cafe for a quick snack. Just as I was about to start eating my turkey, lettuce and tomato pitta bread the song 'Radioactive' by Imagine Dragons came booming out over the radio!  It made me laugh but also starting me thinking about some songs I know and love have new meaning for me now. The song 'Hold On' by Oasis for example starts with these lines hold on....hold on .....don't be scared.....you'll never change what's been and gone. those lines feel very emotional for me now. I wondered if people would like to share songs that hold new meaning or just make them feel good! I'm making a chemo playlist!  Fiona
Posts.Title: Cancer playlist...

Posts.Content: Hello Craftyp  I hope you get some feedback on this ...i am 43 too and my periods stopped half way through chemo once I started T. i very quickly became anaemic after starting that cycle and having had my final chemo last week (yay!) I am still recovering.  I was wondering how long it would take to get back to 'normal'  its horrible when periods are so unpredictable so can understand how you must be feeling. fiona
Posts.Title: Periods returning after chemo

Posts.Content: Hello Liz I am TNBC too.... Diagnosed in October and had surgery mammoplasty, lumpectomy and SNB that month. I started FEC-T 6weeks later. I am in for second cycle on Wednesday.  I had long hair and got it cut short. On day 15 after Chemo it started falling out. I got it cut a little shorter. Within 5 days so much of it was falling out that I cut my husband to clipper it right off. I knew I would lose my hair as was not interested in trying cold cap. I'm bald now and my children are getting used to it now. Nails...I might be wrong about this but I think it's the T part of chemo that may impact on nails. That's cycle 4,5 and 6 so I am going to paint my toe nails and finger ones with strengthener, then black polish, then a grape colour as my goth days are long gone although I would make a good punk with this hair!  I Joined a TNBC facebook group but it was American and it didn't work for me so I left it.  That's great that you want to donate your hair. Some little girl will be very happy with that and what a great thing to do. I am wearing hats...I gave a wig but I'm just not feeling it so far!  Fiona
Posts.Title: Hello Newbie Here

Posts.Content: Thanks Juliet....I have much less hair now but I think I am beginning to get a bit of fuzz that might soon be hair!  the two most difficult times for me were diagnosis and the anxiety I felt before chemo. It has all been so much better since then. I have my 5th cycle on friday and after getting the first chemo done the time has flown past. It's important to do nice things in between cycles especially in the 3rd week when you feel good and have appetite back.  The only other thing I forget to mention and this might be too much information but constipation was a real issue for me throughout. Now take dicoctyl which is much kinder than senna!  i know the unknown is hard to deal with but once the 1st one is done you will probably feel so much better and there is a chemo club thread here too for posting on with tips and advice.  Fiona
Posts.Title: start of chemo

Posts.Content: Hello Juliet i felt very anxious before my first FEC but it wasn't as bad as I feared. i always have a brisk walk before chemo to warm up my body and make the veins work. I always make sure I have some food and time for it to settle in my stomach. i like to have a friend keep me company because it takes my mind off what's happening. the actual process is usually pain free after getting the cannula in. If that's how they are doing it. Some people get Picc line etc.  after chemo is over I usually go to my bed with water within reach and a bowl with wet wipes just in case of sickness. not everyone is sick but I was the first time. The second time I got emend and that stopped the sickness i spent a lot of time sleeping over the first two days...ate a little....drank a lot to get rid of that pink pee you get!  By the third day I was out walking again although a little weepy. your experience might be totally different but for me while unpleasant....it was doable.  hope this helps...any questions just shout! fiona
Posts.Title: start of chemo

Posts.Content: Congratulations! hope you had a lovely day. Thats my birthday! Each year is a blessing.
Posts.Title: Celebration today ...

Posts.Content: Hello Bev i also had a horrible time after my first T and my oncologist said that cycle 4 where you are recovering from FEC and starting T can be the worst time. It was for me and I found that cycle 5 and 6 of T were not as bad. My bone aches started between day 3 and day 5. I did not get mouth ulcers but pain in my feet and a little in my hands.  hope it goes easy on you fiona
Posts.Title: Docetexal

Posts.Content: Hello Petrosa i felt the same as you when I found out the cancer was in my lymph. I was very scared and worried but being told by my surgeon that this was still very treatable was a comfort to me. My tumour was a similar size and I had the surgery 3 months ago. 2 of my lymph nodes had cancer and they were removed during SNB but I will either have further rads or surgery to remove the others once I finish chemo. for me getting a cancer diagnosis was like a bereavement. I couldn't eat or sleep and couldn't stop vomiting. This all began to get better once the appointments started happening. You are also dealing with the sadness of wanting another child and having to deal with this instead. This is very hard and unfair. fear plays such a big part in those early days after diagnosis and people don't know what to say to help. I had people telling me you're young and strong you'll beat this .....you'll be fine. I found this very difficult because of course nobody knew how I would be.  it does get better. My youngest boy is 7 and I have moved forward from wondering if I will see him grow up to accepting that this is my situation and while I am hopeful....I have to learn to cope with uncertainty.  It's really hard but it gets more manageable....that has been my experience.  Fiona
Posts.Title: Stressed out!

Posts.Content: Hello Judy Your mum is being well supported by your family. You are not responsible for her or her feelings. You sound like a very caring and positive person and don't allow pressure and manipulation from others to change that. It is your job to get well just now and not to take on the worry for other family members too. You love your mum and are bound to be concerned but let the family pick up the practical matters in this this situation. You are right to do this and don't waste energy feeling bad or worrying about people's opinions.  Fiona
Posts.Title: Feeling helpless and guilty

Posts.Content: Hello Jane  i like the ideas already posted. It's true as Julia says that our brain often goes into worst case scenario mode.  I did a lot of that kind of thinking in the beginning when I was first diagnosed because I had developed physical symptoms which I thought were indications that my cancer had spread and were secondary. It took 3months between diagnosis, surgery and the outcome of scans before starting chemo for the evidence to show that while the cancer was in my lymph it had not spread further.  During that time I had people telling me that I would be fine etc and that I was young (43) and would beat it etc  Meanwhile I was putting a brave face on while believing that I wouldn't live to see my children grow up. It was intensely painful but I think in some ways perhaps it has made this bit easier. I say this because the only way forward for me at that time was to accept that I had no control over the outcome of the cancer and that I might live, but I also might die.  Once I had accepted that I made the decision that the only thing I could control was how to deal with my diagnosis. Also that if my time with my children was going to be short then I had to make the best of that time. In your situation it sounds as people are telling you that it's positive and your head is telling you to be positive but you are not feeling it.  But you have been through this horrible experience....and finished chemo and perhaps you have not has time to process emotionally just how awful aspects of this have been. Family and friends etc are often to keen for you to be 'positive' and 'strong' that I think we mask our true feelings and stop being authentic.....to protect them from just how terrible it actually is.  Maybe you are playing catch up with feelings that you repressed because you were so busy trying to get better.  I am still half way through chemo so not in a position to give advice but I guess I just wanted to say that I think that the way you are feeling makes sense for where you are at in this experience but that better days are coming for you. You know that cancer has taken time from you that you won't get back but the future (even if it is less certain than it used to be) is yours.  Also come here to talk to people who understand. fiona
Posts.Title: Worried!

Posts.Title: advice on telling my children

Posts.Content: Hello Iona my two are same age as yours but two boys. The boys knew about cancer because my brother aged 38 had just finished treatment for bowel cancer. In this context we were able to explain that while cancer is a serious illness it is something that you get surgery and treatment for and most people are lucky like uncle and get better.  I spent a lot of time explaining that the treatment not the cancer would make me feel unwell and that because if that they might see me crying and being sick.i explained that It us important that they realise that while this horrible it will make me better. They can give me cuddle etc and it's not their fault.  I also explained that you can't catch cancer( apoarently they might worry about that)  i said that we would get through this difficult time as a family and there might be some small practical things they could do to help. I spoke to my eldest after that in private and told him that I would try to answer any questions he had with honesty because he understood and was very upset. Warn your child's teachers at school to be watchful of any changes in behaviour. Mine have been fine after initial wobble. telling them will probably be the most difficult thing you do but afterwards it is much easier because you are no longer pretending...while obviously sptill protecting them from graphic non age appropriate details.  Good luck..... fiona

Posts.Title: Waiting forever!

Posts.Content: hello Rosiemay My heart goes out to you because I know from experience that this bit is really difficult. i found out on the day I went to breast clinic too and had a 3 week wait until the results of the biopsy.  I am 43 and have two children.  I expect your head and your heart is taking you to the worst 'what if scenarios ' when you think of your children.....that was the most difficult thing for me, along with all the questions I didn't yet know the answer too. i can give you advice based on how I got through those days but advice is not easy to follow sometimes. The most important thing to do is to try and eat,sleep and get outside each day. If you have anything you can distract yourself with even for short periods then do it. I started watching the good wife on netflix.....sometimes in the middle of the night. this is obvious ....but read the info they have given you about breast cancer. When you go for your biopsy results they will tell you what type of cancer it is... And what is stimulating it....eg hormones etc. You will find out what what grade the cancer cells are and if you understand these terms and know what that means for your treatment you may find some comfort and feel more in control. You will be worrying about your children most of all I expect. Mine are 7 and 12.... Boys and although telling them was very difficult for me beyond those early difficult days our lives have taken on a different shape but the boys are handling my illness and subsequent treatment very well. We were honest with them but shared age appropriate info. i just had my 4th cycle of chemo yesterday and the treatment is much more manageable than might be expected. fear plays an awful role at the beginning but it does get better as you begin to get the info you need about your diagnosis and the dates start coming on for scans etc  i hope you are managing to sleep and please post with any concerns, questions, anything. There are many kind people on this site who will listen and try to help. We will all be there for you. Fiona

Posts.Title: This worried me at first, now I'm smiling:)

Posts.Content: Hello CEC You are not selfish....this is a scary business and you have every right to feel as you do. We probably all felt that way, I certainly did, and as time passes you learn to find a way to cope but we all still have our wobbles. I joined a yoga class today, its the first exercise I've done apart from walking since I had my surgery and finished chemo. Once the class finished and the teacher asked how I was I burst into tears! I felt totally overwhelmed and I expect there will be lots of times when I feel that way.  I cried so much after diagnosis that there was a period of time when I don't think I had any tears left and I felt quite numb about the whole experience. Seems like emotion is making a comeback for me once more. if you led an active life before that will motivate you to get back to that but there is a period inbetween where you have to accept some physical and emotional changes but these will hopefully be temporary.  I was petrified at the beginning....good word ....but now I feel quite strong emotionally and proud that I got through it. You will too....but for now you have every right to feel any emotion while you come to terms with what's happening.  I couldnt talk to my mum about what was happening to begin with because she would get very upset and I didn't want to be the cause of that. Once I started handling my diagnosis better...so did she....and we're good now. It will get easier.  fiona
